question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: A 19-year-old man in a 3-month relationship with a woman experiences frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers. He lives in a conservative community and does not know any openly gay men. Two days ago, he joined a local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group. Together with the other members, he attacked a gay couple on their way home from dinner. What psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?. If there are multiple answers, separate them with commas. In your explanation, point out what is correct and incorrect in the evidence.

content.source_1: In this case, a 19-year-old man engaged in a 3-month heterosexual relationship reports frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers while residing in a conservative community in which he does not know any openly gay men; two days prior to presentation, he joined a local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group and, alongside other members, attacked a gay couple on their way home from dinner. This pattern is best understood through established psychodynamic constructs in which socially proscribed impulses elicit ego defenses that both conceal and disavow underlying desires. Specifically, the adoption of overtly hostile attitudes and behaviors toward gay individuals—joining a stigmatizing group and participating in an assault—despite concurrent same-sex attraction is consistent with reaction formation, wherein individuals manifest exaggerated oppositional stances that are antithetical to their private impulses to prevent conscious acknowledgment. Concomitantly, the selection of a gay couple as the object of aggression is compatible with projection, the attribution of one’s unacceptable internal wishes to external others. Taken together, the convergence of concealed same-sex attraction, sociocultural constraints, and aggressive antigay enactments supports the following defense mechanisms: Reaction Formation, Projection.
content.source_2: A 19-year-old man in a 3-month relationship with a woman endorses frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers and lives in a conservative community without exposure to any openly gay men; two days ago he joined a local group designated by many organizations as a hate group and participated with its members in an attack on a gay couple returning from dinner. Considering a differential of ego defenses—including denial, projection, reaction formation, repression, displacement, and sublimation—the clinical features indicate primary externalization of unaccepted same-sex attraction. The targeting of a gay couple in the context of disavowed attraction to male coworkers suggests projection, whereby the patient attributes his unacceptable impulses to others and then acts against those perceived qualities. The contemporaneous adoption of an overtly antigay identity by affiliating with a hate group—despite the presence of same-sex fantasies—further supports reaction formation, defined as the substitution of exaggerated attitudes or behaviors opposite to an underlying impulse. On balance, the sequence of disowned desire, hostile attribution to outgroup members, and conspicuous counter-attitudinal affiliation most strongly substantiates Projection, Reaction Formation.
content.source_3: The presentation of a 19-year-old man who, despite a 3-month relationship with a woman, reports frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers and who resides in a conservative community without knowing any openly gay men, followed two days earlier by his joining a local group widely considered a hate group and participating with fellow members in an assault on a gay couple walking home from dinner, reflects a classic intrapsychic conflict managed by multiple defenses. His aggressive antigay enactment in the face of private same-sex attraction is indicative of reaction formation, an ego defense that counters unacceptable impulses by adopting conspicuously opposite attitudes and behaviors; the recent group affiliation amplifies this counter-phobic posture. Concurrently, the selection of a gay couple as the focus of hostility exemplifies projection, in which the patient assigns his own unacceptable erotic impulses to others and then responds to those externalized attributions. The integration of these clinical and contextual elements supports the conclusion of Projection and reaction formation.
